review_title: Progressive employer but IT is shocking

pros: Good team to work with

pros:
The main two hospitals (LGI and SJUH) are largely based in the city centre, so travel times are convenient if choosing to live within the city
LGI is undergoing renovation
cons: Typical for a NHS trust, management is slow to innovate in meeting ever increasing patient needs-often the burden is placed on staff to work consistently beyond their rostered hours in order to prop services. IT systems are not linked effectively with GP services outside of Leeds. This can certainly compromise care given as key medical information within GP records is not available for secondary acute services when required

pros: Lots of opportunities and range of services
cons: Old IT systems and takes a long time to implement a decision

job_title: Human Resources Advisor in Leeds, England
pros: Care staff deliver a good service, secure employment, competitive salaries
cons:
LTHT is incredibly corrupt, institutionally racist and tokenistic. It’s the kind of place where the management teams will wear a rainbow badge for a photo opp whilst pre planning the recruitment and promotion of their friends and chosen successors.

Working here requires me to regularly spend my time running around helping cover up problems or massage egos as the political game of who gets most money continues.

I’ll be getting out as soon as I can, I’d even take a pay cut to leave.

job_title: Trainee Assistant Practitioner in Leeds, England
pros: The opportunity to develop and advance in my career via funded and supported education. Generally flexible working hours. Very knowledgable mentors. catering to the individual needs of staff.
cons: For a teaching hospital and speak as my experience as a current Trainee Assistant Practitioner (TAO). Not all wards are committed to the education of staff and some wards don't like to teach TAP's but will teach student nurses. I feel the role of an AP is not clearly understood and as such wards don't know how to teach us or what to do with us. Many staff are not willing to teach, some wards are not suitable to teach due to the fact they are to busy and lack staffing. The wards that want to teach sadly cant teach as much as they would like due to a lack of students resulting in a lack of mentors. At the moment due to what I feel was a poor first placement I am going through a gruling time trying to play catch up.

pros: Good pay, Good managers and friendly staff
cons: Travel to diffrent outreaches, some nasty staff (children's department) and irregular working hours.

pros: Supportive staff, great communication through the workforce, good training opportunities
cons: Very limited opportunities for progession in my specific area

pros: okay, it depends on you

pros: Good place to work for yeno

job_title: Clinical Nurse Specialist in Leeds, England
pros: Great philosophy of care - the Leeds Way means that we are patient centered, fair, collaborative, accountable and empowered as employees. Our goals are that we want to give the best in patient safety, quality and experience, we want to be the best place to work, we want to be a centre of excellence for specialist services, research, education and innovation,we want to be a hospital that offer seamless, integrated care and we want to be financially sustainable. We are all kept informed about what is happening in the trust, we are cared about and we are listened to and valued.
cons: The cons are that some employees have not yet grasped the importance or inclusivity of the Leeds Way, and always feel that management are keeping something from us - the sooner we all start pulling in the same direction, the quicker our Leeds Way will take us to the top

pros: Working at Leeds Teaching Hospital enabled me to hone my team working skills and deliver patient centred care. The employers are incredibly supportive and host numerous free management courses. Any work related issues are handled with great sensitivity and promptly resolved.
cons:
The restaurant could most certainly be healthier. However, with a new M&S store, it caters for the health conscious staff where calories, sugar content, fat etc are clearly labelled. 

Patients are unhappy with the lack of smoking facilities and choose to smoke with no regard to location.

job_title: Medical Illustration Support Worker in Leeds, England
pros: The department I joined were so unbelievably caring and welcoming, and couldn't help you enough. They are always keen to help you learn and progress. They are also extremely flexible when it comes to personal commitments. We are all just a bunch of happy people who put the patients first :)
cons: Obviously budget cuts do sometimes make it difficult but that's to be expected. There is always a need for more staff but we make it work.

pros: Leeds Way Values have changed this place for the better, lots of chances of promotion, if you are willing to learn and better yourself, you don’t get anywhere without hard work. If you are willing to work hard the sky’s the limit.
cons: Some negative staff remain, not understanding that they don’t have to work there it’s not compulsory! Negative staff try to bring positive staff down to their level.

pros: LTHT Is a good employer in terms on wages and job security. Its good to know my wage will arrive in my bank every month without fail.
cons: I feel management could listen to lower banded staff more but overall not a bad employer. Also, staff have to pay for parking.

pros: Excellent facilities, Salary pay with sick pay and holiday. Strong job stability, there's always sick people. kmowing that you're making an impact, knowing that you've tried your best and helped someone else.
cons: long time staff who do not understand or respect people who are younger than them working to a higher point and achieving a better pay grade because they were selected for a university course

pros: Secure employment, good co-workers, can't take work stress home with you
cons: No opportunity for progression without becoming management (at not enough pay), no opportunity for flexible working unless you have children
